casebody.data:
Larry N. WHITE, Petitioner-Appellant, v. Rick V. VEACH, Respondent-Appellee. No. 06-3941. United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit. Submitted March 8, 2007 *. Decided March 12, 2007. Rehearing En Banc Denied April 5, 2007. Larry N. White, Terre Haute, IN, pro se. Gerald A. Coraz, Office of the United States Attorney, Indianapolis, IN, for Respondent-Appellee.

Before Hon. DANIEL A. MANION, Circuit Judge, Hon. MICHAEL S. KANNE, Circuit Judge and Hon. DIANE P. WOOD, Circuit Judge.

After examining the briefs and the record, we have concluded that oral argument is unnecessary. Thus, the appeal is submitted on the briefs and the record. See Fed. R.App. P. 34(a)(2).

ORDER

Larry White was convicted of participating in a conspiracy to distribute cocaine that began in 1980 and ended in September 1988. Because the offense ended after the Sentencing Reform Act became effective on November 1, 1987, he was sentenced pursuant to that act, which abolished parole. In a habeas corpus petition filed under 28 U.S.C. § 2241, White argues that he is nonetheless entitled to parole. The district court denied relief, and White appeals. We affirm.

White first maintains that the Sentencing Reform Act is inapplicable to him since the conspiracy he joined began before that act became effective. This argument is without merit. White’s conspiracy ended in 1988, well after the effective date of the Sentencing Reform Act, and we have repeatedly held that a conspiracy *513that straddles the effective date of this Act is subject to it. See United States v. Osborne, 931 F.2d 1139, 1144 (7th Cir.1991); United States v. Fazio, 914 F.2d 950, 958-59 (7th Cir.1990).

White also seems to contend that he is eligible for parole since, as he understands it, Congress did not abolish parole for conspiracy offenses until it amended 21 U.S.C. § 846 on November 18, 1988. See National Narcotics Leadership Act of 1988, Pub.L. No. 100-690, § 6470. 102 Stat. 4377. This contention is incorrect. It was the Sentencing Reform Act itself that abolished parole, not the unrelated amendment to § 846. See Sentencing Reform Act of 1984, Pub.L. No. 98-473, § 218(a)(5), 98 Stat.2027; Skowronek v. Brennan, 896 F.2d 264, 266 (7th Cir.1990), see also Osborne, 931 F.2d at 1145 (applying Sentencing Reform Act to conspiracy that ended after Act’s effective date but before November 1998 amendment to § 846).

AFFIRMED.
